page.title: 14The Eel Trap, Alrewas
page.content: There is only one item from the original Domesday Book that is still in existance. It is written that Alrewas was retained for the King because of the eel trap. It yielded 1,000 eels per annum. The mill has owned the trap since 1614 when it was repaired. The flood gates across the river (now removed) controlled the flow of water to the mill. The trap was reached across the top of the gates. The eels were caught in the shallows whilst sun- ning themselves. The river was diverted in the 1970's and no longer flows through the trap. Some original stonework remains, but most of the structure is later brick. The tunnel is 8ft 7ins wide and 10 ft long. There is a small opening with a gate at one end. The other end is open.
